citations.narrative:
Three enclosures were too small for the dogs they contained. One enclosure measuring 45 inches by 25 inches provided
1,125 square inches of space. The enclosure contained two four month old bichons measuring 19 inches and 17 inches
respectively. Together the dogs required 1,154 square inches of space. The enclosure was short by 29 square inches of
space. Another enclosure measured 32 inches by 32.25 inches and provided 1,032 square inches of space. The
enclosure contained 3 8-week old puppies. Two were Schnauzers and one was a Dachshund. The puppies measures 12
inches, 13 inches, and 14 inches respectively. Together they required 1,085 square inches of space. The enclosure was
short by 53 square inches of space. A third enclosure measured 25 inches by 56 inches providing 1,400 square inches of
space. The enclosure contained three 11-week old Dachshund puppies. The puppies measured 16.5 inches, 16.5 inches,
and 15 inches respectively. Together the puppies required 1,453.5 square inches of space. The enclosure was short by
53.5 square inches of space.
Cage space requirements ensure the dogs have enough room to move about freely within their enclosures. It minimizes
the dogs from stepping or sitting in their feces or urine and also minimizes the spread of disease. The licensee must
ensure all enclosures containing dogs and puppies have enough floor space to meet the minimum floor space
requirements for the number of and the size of the dogs in that enclosure.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
Rodent droppings were seen on top of the closed food storage containers as well as in one enclosure housing one adult
pug. There were dead flies present in the water receptacles of at least six dog enclosures. Pests like flies and rodents can
spread disease and contaminate food and water supplies. The licensee must have a safe and effective pest control
program in place to protect the health and well being of the animals.
To be corrected by 7-11-25.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
End of report.
Additional Inspectors:
KEVIN WILKEN, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n

narrative:
3.6(c)(1)(i)  Repeat
   
Primary enclosures. 
Three enclosures were too small for the dogs they contained. One enclosure measuring 45 inches by 25 inches provided 
1,125 square inches of space. The enclosure contained two four month old bichons measuring 19 inches and 17 inches 
respectively. Together the dogs required 1,154 square inches of space. The enclosure was short by 29 square inches of 
space. Another enclosure measured 32 inches by 32.25 inches and provided 1,032 square inches of space. The 
enclosure contained 3 8-week old puppies. Two were Schnauzers and one was a Dachshund. The puppies measures 12 
inches, 13 inches, and 14 inches respectively. Together they required 1,085 square inches of space. The enclosure was 
short by 53 square inches of space. A third enclosure measured 25 inches by 56 inches providing 1,400 square inches of 
space. The enclosure contained three 11-week old Dachshund puppies. The puppies measured 16.5 inches, 16.5 inches, 
and 15 inches respectively. Together the puppies required 1,453.5 square inches of space. The enclosure was short by 
53.5 square inches of space. 
 
Cage space requirements ensure the dogs have enough room to move about freely within their enclosures. It minimizes 
the dogs from stepping or sitting in their feces or urine and also minimizes the spread of disease. The licensee must 
ensure all enclosures containing dogs and puppies have enough floor space to meet the minimum floor space 
requirements for the number of and the size of the dogs in that enclosure. 
3.11(d) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
Rodent droppings were seen on top of the closed food storage containers as well as in one enclosure housing one adult 
pug. There were dead flies present in the water receptacles of at least six dog enclosures. Pests like flies and rodents can 
spread disease and contaminate food and water supplies. The licensee must have a safe and effective pest control 
program in place to protect the health and well being of the animals. 
To be corrected by 7-11-25. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
End of report.

Additional Inspectors: 
KEVIN WILKEN, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n
